title.narrative: Climate Change linked with Food Security

description.narrative:
Building knowledge base on #Climate Change linked with Food Security <(>&<)> Right to Food# in Pakistan
This project is aligned with the Grow plans for next years among the two affiliates and will provide the foundation by building the knowledge base acrossa wide range of audiences. Within this project Oxfam GB will endeavour to build linkages with Academic Institutes by initiating the critical debate on linkages between food security <(>&<)> climate change by organizing seminars. This is crucial to enhance the knowledgebase within the students and staff of the agriculture universities. Capacity building of civil society and community representativeon the above linkages # food security <(>&<)> climate change - is necessary and will be built through this project. Right to Food is a new area of campaigning work within Oxfam in Pakistan and capacity building sessions one of Oxfam Staff <(>&<)> one of its partners will build the foundation for future endeavours in this domain. Food insecurity is increasing in Pakistan. According to NationalNutrition Survey 2011 58% of the households are foods insecure. Sustainable Development Policy Institute (SDPI) concluded the same in 2009. According to it #the state of food security in Pakistan has deteriorated since 2003; the conditionsfor food security were inadequate in 45% districts in 2003 which stood 61 percent districts in 2009. Right to Food is a wide area of work in Pakistan. Constitutional statements and Pakistan#s approval of global conventions, for instance ICESCR, UDHR gives a clear endorsement to people#s Right to Food, however these when translated in to the policy framework is subdued by numerous factors. Furthermore the right to food is being translated at the grass root level within the framework of various policies and acts. For engaging on RtF campaigning a clear demarcation and understanding amongst civil society does not exist, since there are a number of factors which realize RtF or contribute to this. In Pakistan, various forums, networks and bodies are campaigning and advocating for the people#s right to food, however a coherent understanding and contextual alignment does not exist.

participating-org.narrative: The counterpart is Oxfam Great Britain in Pakistan.Oxfam is an international confederation of 17 organizations working together in more than 90 countries. Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together for greater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice. The name “Oxfam” comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War. As well as becoming a world leader in the delivery of emergency relief, Oxfam International implements long-term development programs invulnerable communities. We are also part of a global movement, campaigning with others, for instance, to end unfair trade rules, demand better health and education services for all, and to combat climate change. Today, there are 17 member organizations of the Oxfam International confederation. They are based in: Australia, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Ireland, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Quebec, Spain and the United States. The Oxfam International Secretariat is based in Oxford, UK. The Secretariat runs advocacy offices in Brussels, Geneva, New York, Washington DC and Brasilia. Oxfam GB is an actor in the implementation of this project.
